awd_titl_txt: A Bio-orthogonal Approach for Identifying Direct Kinase Substrates and their phosphorylation sites
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Kavita Shah from Purdue University. The investigator is developing a high-throughput chemical tool to identify and validate the direct targets of a class of enzymes called kinases. Kinases are key cell regulators that perform phosphorylation reactions with proteins in the cell. They have an important role in biological outcomes that support each tissue's unique physiology. It is estimated that ~33,000 proteins are phosphorylated by kinases in a cell. At present, it is a formidable endeavor to identify each of the 518 human kinases. This project is developing special probes, with exquisite sensitivity for specifically tagging and isolating kinase targets. This method is widely applicable and could be used to identify and validate the targets of any desired kinase in cells. This project allows graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdoctoral fellows to acquire highly interdisciplinary training. The scientific areas of training include chemical synthesis, protein engineering, and enzymatic assays. This project is integrated into an outreach program which consists of an interdisciplinary Chemical Biology course. This course is designed for Chemistry majors and graduate students. It also comprises part of a research training program for under-represented undergraduates recruited through specific programs at Purdue University. The Chemical Biology course is also used as a professional development opportunity for high school teachers. The overall goal is to increase STEM education and retention for high school students, under-represented minorities, and graduate students.

The goal of this proposal is to develop a high-throughput bio-orthogonal chemical approach that enables rapid identification of low abundance kinase substrates and their phosphorylation sites on a proteome-wide scale. A "catch and release" strategy, in combination with an innovative chemical genetic approach, is used to specifically label with a unique phospho-tag, the substrates of any desired kinase of interest. The exquisite sensitivity of this approach stems from the phospho-tag, which will be used to selectively isolate substrates from the whole proteome, without the need for any other separation techniques. These substrates are validated in a high throughput screen using CRISPR-engineered cell lines and orthogonal inhibitors. A few chosen substrates are used as cues to uncover the mechanisms by which these kinases regulate various cellular processes, potentially leading to the discovery of novel pathways and networks. A rapid and comprehensive analysis of a desired kinase's substrates and their phosphorylation sites is crucial for dissecting the contribution of the kinase in activating distinct signaling cascades.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Humans have over 500 enzymes called kinases that modify more than 50,000 proteins in each cell by a chemical reaction called phosphorylation. These modifications change the functions of these proteins, which in turn regulate cell behavior that support each tissue’s unique physiology. As a result, kinases are tightly regulated in cells. However, in almost all human diseases, kinases are deregulated, making them highly attractive drug targets. Currently, there are 50 FDA-approved kinase drugs on the market. Recent advances in mass spectroscopy have enabled rapid profiling of all phosphorylated proteins present in the cells or in tissues, however, it still remains a challenge to uniquely identify all the phosphorylation targets of any individual kinase of interest in the presence of other kinases. Moreover, each of these kinases can phosphorylate hundreds of proteins in each cell, further complicating the entire process. This proposal has successfully developed an approach that allows identification of numerous kinase substrates in a high throughput manner for any desired kinase. We have further utilized this approach to uncover several unknown functions of kinases in human health and disease.

 

Broader Impact

 

The educational plan for this proposal exploited our interdisciplinary research program to train and motivate young students at undergraduate and high-school level. For the first education objective, our goal was to increase High School STEM education by providing professional development opportunities to high school teachers. We developed chemical biology assays-based curriculum appropriate for high school laboratories. We invited High School teachers from Indiana and Illinois and trained them in these assays, which they then successfully implemented in their classrooms. In 2020, as a consequence of Covid 19, we were unable to invite students or teachers for more than two years. Therefore, we created several videos to train students and teachers online. We also created videos with K-12 students on Covid mRNA vaccine and gene editing. Our second educational objective is to train under-represented undergraduates recruited through specific programs at Purdue including MARC/AIM, SROP, REU Chemical Biology and LSAMP (an NSF funded program) in Chemical Biology. During the funding period we hosted nine students through REU and LSAMP programs. These students gained extensive hands-on experience in a variety of techniques ranging from molecular cloning and chemical and biological assays. Our graduate and undergraduate students participated in these training programs to encourage a mutually beneficial celebration of interdisciplinary science.


Last Modified: 08/02/2022
Modified by: Kavita Shah
